Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEACH: Does phenotypic evidence support ecological speciation in western long-eared Myotis bats?
Award.AbstractNarration:
How species are formed is a central question in evolutionary biology. One process involved in species formation is known as ecological speciation, which occurs when different environments promote genetic diversification in a geographically widespread species. It is particularly useful to investigate and model this process in organisms that naturally disperse widely, such as bats. This project will explore differences within and among closely related species of the western long-eared Myotis bats. A novel aspect of this work will be the development of an analytical framework that tests for correlations between phenotypes and genotypes while controlling for environmental variation. This analytical pipeline will be made publicly available, and may be used to test the predictions of ecological speciation in a variety of different organisms. Results from this work will also have important practical implications to bat conservation efforts. To communicate findings from this research to a broader audience, an online interactive museum focused on the tempo and mode of speciation of Myotis bats will be developed.

This research will identify phenotypic evidence of ecological speciation in western long-eared Myotis bats of North America by co-analyzing genomic, morphological, and environmental data. Previous findings demonstrate that these species follow a pattern of speciation-with-gene-flow that might have been promoted by environmental changes. Therefore the hypothesis that morphological differentiation among these bat species is associated with both divergence-with-gene-flow patterns and environmental variation will be tested. Specifically, craniodental shape and size variation among these species across different environments will be examined, using geometric morphometric approaches. A novel approach that accounts for both genetic and environmental covariation on morphometric differences within and among species will be developed. This framework will use geometric morphometrics coupled with environmental niche and genomic scan analyses to identify outlier loci that may have evolved under divergent selection. Finally, this new framework will be applied to predict morphometric variation among the western long-eared bats and differentiate between phenotypic convergence and gene flow among species. This integrative approach will allow us to understand the tempo and mode of speciation of Myotis bats from a phenotypic, genetic and environmental perspective.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With approximately 130 species, the Vespertillionid bat genus Myotis is one of the most speciose general of mammals. The dissertation research seeks to identify phenotypic evidence of ecological speciation in the western long-eared (WLE) Myotis bats of North America by co-analyzing genomic, morphological, and environmental data. Ecological speciation occurs when divergent selection between ecological environments drives the evolution of reproductive isolation. Our work has produced the most comprehensive (in terms of number of species) and well supported (in terms of the amount of data) phylogeny of the genus Myotis to date. The evolutionary relationships within Myotis clearly demonstrate that three different morphologies have repeatedly evolved in this genus, strongly implying that adaptation to local environmental conditions drives morphological change in this clade.  Given these results, a landscape scale investigation of WLE species was conducted. It identified a pattern of speciation-with-gene-flow. Environmental conditions are predictive of craniodental shape and size variation among the WLE bats, consistent with the theory that ecological speciation promotes divergence within Myotis. 


Intellectual merit: The interaction between genotype and environment has a great effect on diversification patterns, including phylogenetic divergence and morphological variation among taxa. To understand patterns of trait variation among species it is necessary to jointly estimate the effects of a hierarchically structured phylogeny and the environment in which species live (i.e. the environmental niche). This dissertation work developed a novel approach that accounts for both genetic and environmental effects on trait variation. The method relies on geometric morphometrics, genomic scans to identify outlier loci, as well as geostatistical models (i.e., kriging) and machine learning algorithms that consider spatial dependence (i.e., cubist, random forest). The investigation, once published, will lead to a comprehensive understanding of the effects of phylogenetic history and environmental features on morphological variation in a diverse genus of bats. 


Broader impacts: This project will publicize a new approach to account for environmental and genetic effects on trait variation among related species. All R scripts developed for this project will be made available online via GitHub as well as archived with the papers. To communicate our findings to a broader audience, we are in the process of developing an online interactive museum focused on the tempo and mode speciation of the WLE bats. This museum will include images and measurements of craniodental traits from specimens of WLE bats linked to genomic and ecological patterns of differentiation between species, and be freely available via MorphoBank for research and education purposes. The proposed project  greatly improved the skillset of the coPI and helped her to publish her dissertation work in broadly read journals.
